Chu-ko-nu: A Reliable, Efficient, and Anonymously Authentication-Enabled Realization for Multi-Round Secure Aggregation in Federated Learning

Kaiping Cui
City University of Macau ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Xia Feng
City University of Macau ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Liangmin Wang
Southeast University ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Haiqin Wu
East China Normal University ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Xiaoyu Zhang
Southeast University ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Boris D√ºdder
University of Copenhagen
Abstract

Secure aggregation enables federated learning (FL) to perform collaborative training of clients from local gradient updates without exposing raw data. However, existing secure aggregation schemes inevitably perform an expensive fresh setup per round because each client needs to establish fresh input-independent secrets over different rounds. The latest research, Flamingo (S&P 2023), designed a share-transfer-based reusable secret key to support the server continuously performing multiple rounds of aggregation. Nevertheless, the share transfer mechanism it proposed can only be achieved with P~~ùëÉ\widetilde{P} probability111The discussion and calculation of probability P~~ùëÉ\widetilde{P} are presented in D.2 and D.3 of Appendix D., which has limited reliability. Besides, most secure aggregation schemes ignore client identity authentication and privacy protection issues, which makes the real identities of clients vulnerable to leakage and the server unable to distinguish clients with forged identities.

To tackle the aforementioned problems, we propose a more reliable and anonymously authenticated scheme called Chu-ko-nu for multi-round secure aggregation. Specifically, in terms of share transfer, Chu-ko-nu breaks the probability P~~ùëÉ\widetilde{P} barrier by supplementing a redistribution process of secret key components (the sum of all components is the secret key), thus ensuring the reusability of the secret key. Based on this reusable secret key, Chu-ko-nu can efficiently perform consecutive aggregation in the following rounds. Furthermore, considering the client identity authentication and privacy protection issue most approaches ignore, Chu-ko-nu introduces a zero-knowledge proof-based authentication mechanism. It can support clients anonymously participating in FL training and enables the server to authenticate clients effectively in the presence of various attacks. Rigorous security proofs and extensive experiments demonstrated that Chu-ko-nu can provide reliable and anonymously authenticated aggregation for FL with low aggregation costs, at least a 21.02% reduction compared to the state-of-the-art schemes.

1 Introduction

As a distributed training pattern, Federated Learning (FL) enables clients (e.g., mobile devices) collaboratively training a global model under the assistance of an aggregation server. Specifically, in each round of training, the server transmits the current global model to a randomly pre-selected subset of clients. These clients iteratively train the received model on its local dataset over several epochs and subsequently upload the training gradient to the server. Afterwards, the server updates the global model based on the collected gradients from the clients. The global model requires multiple such rounds of training and updating until convergence. Although FL provides a promising method enabling the model training to be carried out without exposing the raw data, the prior works show that the clients‚Äô gradients will still leak sensitive information about the raw data [1, 2, 3, 4]; thus, the requirement of secure aggregation is highlighted.

Numerous secure aggregation protocols applied in FL scenarios have been proposed [5, 6, 7, 8]. At first glance, existing secure aggregation protocols are suitable for the FL‚Äôs characteristics, for instance, achieving privacy protection for clients‚Äô local gradients, tolerating devices dropping out before completing the gradient aggregation, and enhancing the reliability of model parameters. In terms of implementation principles, specifically, these protocols select a subset of clients as participants in each round of aggregation, and then each participant is required to establish negotiated secrets with several other clients (called ‚Äúneighbors‚Äù) during the setup phase. These secrets are utilized to mask the participants‚Äô training gradients and cannot be reused for privacy reasons. Thus, these protocols are inevitable to perform the expensive fresh system setup per round. Besides, when dealing with dropped clients during the collection phase, the server must interact with all neighbors of the dropped client to recover its mask, incurring unaffordable communication costs.

In order to tackle the aforementioned problems in the existing secure aggregation protocols, Ma et al.[9] proposed Flamingo, the multi-round aggregation scheme supporting full sessions of training in the stringent FL setting. Flamingo has multiple excellent features in terms of secure aggregation (the more detailed introduction is presented in Section 2.5). Among those, there are two crucial technological innovations reusable secret and lightweight dropout resilience. Briefly, Flamingo proposes a share transfer mechanism to support the reusability of secret across rounds of aggregation and further achieves lightweight dropout resilience. However, due to the high autonomy of clients, existing share transfer mechanism can only enable the secret reuse process to be realized with a P~~ùëÉ\widetilde{P} probability (details of the discussion are presented in Appendix D), which seriously affects the reliability of Flamingo.

Moreover, there are some identity privacy protection issues in secure aggregation schemes, especially when applied to open communication network scenarios (e.g., the Internet of Vehicles) [10, 11, 12, 13]. In this respect, on the one hand, although the prior works regarding secure aggregation for FL suffice for the security and confidentiality of raw data, the protection of client identity information (e.g., identity certificates and activity trajectory) is insufficient; on the other hand, the server is unable to verify the legitimacy of clients participating in the FL training, which makes the FL system extremely vulnerable to security and privacy threats[14]. For instance, clients participating in the secure aggregation are non-anonymous, which may lead to clients‚Äô behaviors being tracked or monitored and information leakage of their real identities[15, 16].

In order to provide a fruitful countermeasure for the aforementioned dilemmas, in this paper, we present an authentication-enabled multi-round secure aggregation scheme (called Chu-ko-nu) while achieving privacy protection for clients. The main contributions are presented as follows:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Reliable share transfer mechanism. While inheriting the excellent features of the Flamingo, Chu-ko-nu constructs a redistribution process of secret key components (the sum of all components is the secret key) to achieve a reliable transfer phase for secret key shares in each round, which ensures the reusability of the secret key. With the assistance of this reusable secret key, Chu-ko-nu can efficiently perform consecutive aggregation operations in the following rounds.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Anonymous authentication. Our scheme introduces a zero-knowledge proof-based authentication mechanism. On the one hand, the authentication mechanism enables the server to effectively verify the client participating in the FL training while resisting various attacks, such as impersonation attacks and replay attacks; on the other hand, the authentication mechanism supports clients to anonymously upload local gradients, ensuring that the identity information is not leaked.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Performance evaluation. We construct a prototype to demonstrate the functional performance. The data obtained from the experiment are persuasive evidence that our scheme has lower overall costs compared with the state-of-the-art schemes. Besides, the security analysis indicates that our scheme can provide reliable security and privacy protection properties.

The remainder of our paper is organized as follows: We outline the preliminary in Section 2. The system architecture and details of our proposal are formalized in Section 3. We implement an analysis of security and evaluate the performance of our proposal in Sections 4 and 5, respectively. We introduce some related work in Section 6. Finally, we conclude our paper and present the future work in Section 7.

2 Preliminary

In this section, for ease of understanding of this paper, we elaborate on the underlying cryptographic building blocks of our proposed scheme, the communication model, and the threat model.

2.1 Cryptographic Building Blocks

In this subsection, we introduce some cryptographic building blocks, such as Pseudo-random generator (PRG), Shamir‚Äôs secret sharing, and the Decisional Diffie-Hellman (DDH) assumption. Due to space limitations, we present their formal definitions in Appendix A.

2.2 Communication Model

In our scheme, wireless communication is constructed between clients and server. Besides, similar to [9], information exchange between clients are forwarded via the server.

2.3 Threat Model

In this paper, we assume that the server is semi-trusted, which can perform the prescribed gradient aggregation protocol, but is curious about the clients‚Äô real gradient and reusable secret key S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK. Besides, there are two categories of factors that affect the secure aggregation process: (1) Clients dropping out prior to completing the aggregation protocol or do not respond to server requests before timeout; (2) The server or a bounded fraction of the clients is controlled by adversaries. The details are as follows:

Dropouts. In each round of aggregation, the server needs to interact with the clients multiple times. However, not all clients can optimally participate in all steps of the aggregation process. A fraction of clients may be offline or unresponsive before a particular step due to unstable network conditions, etc. The proposed scheme divides all clients in [N]delimited-[]ùëÅ[N] into two categories during each round of aggregation: regular clients and decryptors. The set consisting of regular clients selected to perform local training and upload gradients in any round tùë°t is defined as StsubscriptùëÜùë°S_{t}, with the upper bound of the dropout fraction defined as Œ¥StsubscriptùõøsubscriptùëÜùë°\delta_{S_{t}}. The clients selected as decryptors (the set of decryptors is denoted as Dtsubscriptùê∑ùë°D_{t}, St‚à©Dt=‚àÖsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùê∑ùë°S_{t}\cap D_{t}=\emptyset) are responsible for assisting the server in decrypting the mask to calculate the final aggregation result, with the upper bound of the dropout fraction defined as Œ¥Dtsubscriptùõøsubscriptùê∑ùë°\delta_{D_{t}}.

Adversary. We assume that a static and malicious set of adversaries can corrupt the server and up to an Œ∑ùúÇ\eta fraction of the total NùëÅN clients. There are two stated assumptions in the proposed scheme: (1) The set consisting of compromised clients executes independently of the aggregation, remaining unchanged throughout the entire FL process; (2) Malicious clients can also be randomly offline, but the dropout fraction of malicious clients is not considered in Œ¥StsubscriptùõøsubscriptùëÜùë°\delta_{S_{t}} or Œ¥Dtsubscriptùõøsubscriptùê∑ùë°\delta_{D_{t}}. Similar to the dropout model, in any aggregation round tùë°t, the upper bound fraction of corrupted regular clients and decryptors in StsubscriptùëÜùë°S_{t} is Œ∑StsubscriptùúÇsubscriptùëÜùë°\eta_{S_{t}} and Œ∑DtsubscriptùúÇsubscriptùê∑ùë°\eta_{D_{t}} (Œ∑St+Œ∑Dt=Œ∑subscriptùúÇsubscriptùëÜùë°subscriptùúÇsubscriptùê∑ùë°ùúÇ\eta_{S_{t}}+\eta_{D_{t}}=\eta), respectively; Œ∑DtsubscriptùúÇsubscriptùê∑ùë°\eta_{D_{t}} is upper bounded by Œ∫‚ÄãŒ∑ùúÖùúÇ\kappa\eta with probability 2‚àíŒò‚Äã(Œ∫)superscript2ŒòùúÖ2^{-\Theta(\kappa)}, where Œ∫ùúÖ\kappa is a statistical security parameter.

Threshold requirement. In the proposed scheme, the number of decryptors selected in any round of tùë°t satisfies L=3‚Äãl+1ùêø3ùëô1L=3l+1. Therefore, the minimum requirement for the secure execution of this scheme is Œ¥Dt+Œ∑Dt<1/3subscriptùõøsubscriptùê∑ùë°subscriptùúÇsubscriptùê∑ùë°13\delta_{D_{t}}+\eta_{D_{t}}<1/3.

2.4 Secure Aggregation

Secure aggregation has a wide range of applications in many fields [17, 18, 19]. Among that, one significant application is Federated learning (FL). In practice, a server wishes to train a model using data belonging to various clients, but the clients do not wish to expose (or contribute) their local data. An ideal approach is that each client receives the global model defined by the server and uses local data training to obtain private gradients. Therefore, in each training round, the server only needs to calculate the latest gradient update results (e.g., using the FedAvg algorithm [20]) based on the received gradient vectors from clients to update the global model further.

We define the set of integers {1,2,‚ãØ,n}12‚ãØùëõ\{1,2,\cdots,n\} as [n]delimited-[]ùëõ[n] and formalize one round of FL as follows. We assume a total of TùëáT rounds of FL training are required for model convergence, and the number of total clients is NùëÅN (each client is indexed with a number i‚àà[N]ùëñdelimited-[]ùëÅi\in[N]). More concretely, in a training round t‚àà[T]ùë°delimited-[]ùëát\in[T], a set St‚äÜ[N]subscriptùëÜùë°delimited-[]ùëÅS_{t}\subseteq[N] is randomly selected. Based on the received global model from the server, each client i‚ààStùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°i\in S_{t} computes a gradient vector x‚Üíi,tsubscript‚Üíùë•ùëñùë°\overrightarrow{x}_{i,t} using local data. Afterwards, the server wishes to securely receive x‚Üíi,tsubscript‚Üíùë•ùëñùë°\overrightarrow{x}_{i,t} from each client i‚ààStùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°i\in S_{t} and compute the sum of received gradient vectors ‚àëi‚ààStx‚Üíi,tsubscriptùëñsubscriptùëÜùë°subscript‚Üíùë•ùëñùë°\sum_{i\in S_{t}}\overrightarrow{x}_{i,t}.

2.5 The Flamingo Protocol

Traditional secure aggregation schemes are designed for a single round. Briefly, the aggregation schemes have to repeat multiple times to adapt to FL scenarios, which can result in unbearable overhead. The Flamingo protocol [9] breaks this barrier and achieves multi-round secure aggregation, which mainly includes the following excellent features:

  • (1)

    Reusable secret. Flamingo introduces a secret reuse mechanism, i.e., the secret established in the setup can be reused across rounds of aggregation. Therefore, Flamingo removes the requirement to perform a fresh setup process in each round of aggregation. Especially, a reusable key pair (S‚ÄãK,P‚ÄãK)ùëÜùêæùëÉùêæ(SK,PK) is calculated in the setup phase to support lightweight dropout resilience. The public key P‚ÄãKùëÉùêæPK is a parameter known to any entity, which is utilized to encrypt the seed that computes pairwise masks. The secret key S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK is stored in the decryptors in the form of shares222Shares of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK are generated based on the secret sharing mechanism (i.e., S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK can be reconstructed by shares satisfying threshold requirement), and each decryptor holds a unique share. What Flamingo expects is that shares can be transformed and transferred between decryptors in different rounds, but S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK remains unchanged.. In order to eliminate the massive costs generated by regenerating S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK per round and realize the reuse of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK across rounds of aggregation, Flamingo attempts to design a share transfer mechanism to generate new shares for the decryptors selected for the upcoming round of aggregation.

  • (2)

    Lightweight dropout resilience. Flamingo designs a lightweight mask removal strategy (the same is valid for mask recovery of dropout), i.e., the server only needs to interact with a small subset of clients (called ‚Äúdecryptor‚Äù). When addressing the dropout that is a neighbor of a particular online client (assume client iùëñi), the server sends a request regarding mask recovery to the decryptors. Using the local share of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK, decryptors calculate the partial decryption parameter of the encrypted seed negotiated by dropout and client iùëñi. Afterwards, the server can recover the mask of the dropout based on l+1ùëô1l+1 received partial decryption parameters.

  • (3)

    Per-round graphs. The traditional aggregation protocol needs to perform the fresh selection procedure for the clients participating in each round of aggregation [21]. Thus, correspondingly, the protocol has to establish the sparse graph (e.g., [5]) per round. In order to overcome this shortcoming and adapt to the multi-round aggregation pattern, Flamingo proposed a novel graph generation algorithm, which support clients unilaterally determining the utilization of pairwise masks per round.

In sum, the full protocol of Flamingo proposed an advanced multi-round aggregation concept and designed an excellent aggregation architecture.

3 An Authentication-enabled Multi-Round Secure Aggregation

In this section, we present details of the proposed scheme. More concretely, we first define basic parameters in Section 3.1. Afterwards, we describe the Setup Phase in Section 3.2 and the Collection Phase in Section 3.3. In addition, we highlight the proposed novel share transfer mechanism in Section 3.4 and discuss the related design motivations. Since Chu-ko-nu is an extension of Flamingo[9], the system framework does not alter significantly, as shown in Figure 1. The detailed protocol for each round is fully presented in Appendix E.

3.2 Setup Phase

The Setup Phase mainly involves two parts of work: (1) Entity registration (2) Prescribed graph generation, and (3) Secret key share distribution. We introduce each part in detail below.

Entity registration. In our scheme, a trusted institution RA with sufficient computing power is responsible for the entity‚Äôs identity registration process. Here, the entities contain clients and the institutions that maintain servers. It should be noted that the registration process is conducted in a secure channel or offline. Taking the client as an example, the registration process is as follows:

    The client transmits the real identity I‚ÄãDùêºùê∑ID and c‚Äãp‚Äãkùëêùëùùëòcpk to RA through a secure communication channel or offline.

    RA returns a parameter set {P‚ÄãI‚ÄãD,Œî‚ÄãT,p‚Äãs‚Äãk}ùëÉùêºùê∑Œîùëáùëùùë†ùëò\{PID,\Delta T,psk\} to the client via a secure channel.

Secret key share distribution. The key pair (S‚ÄãK,P‚ÄãK)ùëÜùêæùëÉùêæ(SK,PK) is generated jointly by a subset of clients. It is worth noting that the secret key S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK is invisible to any entity (based on the threat model, the client or adversary cannot recover the secret key through shares it holds). The key pair (S‚ÄãK,P‚ÄãK)ùëÜùêæùëÉùêæ(SK,PK) is utilized to encrypt/decrypt the seed S~~ùëÜ\widetilde{S}. We will outline the key pair generation process in Appendix F. It is important to note: (1) Since the key calculation mode will affect the mask recovery in the subsequent operations, we will focus on analyzing its calculation details; (2) The share distribution process is implemented with Distributed Key Generation algorithm (DKG), which is defined in Appendix A.

3.3 Collection Phase

There are three main steps in each round tùë°t: Report, Cross-check, and Reconstruction. It is emphasized that the subsequent transfer phase profoundly impacts the Reconstruction step, and we will present specific calculation details of both. Besides, the related cryptographic primitives are formalized in Appendix A.

Besides, our proposal authorizes regular clients to go offline at any time following the Report step. Therefore, in the gradient aggregation process, the server needs to recover mi,tsubscriptùëöùëñùë°m_{i,t} for online clients and hi,j,tsubscript‚Ñéùëñùëóùë°h_{i,j,t} for offline clients. In brief, the server labels the client as ‚Äúonline‚Äù or ‚Äúoffline‚Äù based on whether the client responds to its request within the timeout and sends the label information of all clients in StsubscriptùëÜùë°S_{t} to each decryptor d‚ààD3ùëësubscriptùê∑3d\in D_{3}. Each decryptor signs the labels and sends them through the server to other decryptors. Afterwards, each decryptor checks whether at least 2‚ÄãL/32ùêø32L/3 valid signed labels have been received.   • ‚Ä¢

    All the online clients in the graph are connected.

  • ‚Ä¢

If the above conditions are satisfied, the server can compute the aggregation result; otherwise, the honest decryptors abort, and the server cannot obtain anything.

3.4 Transfer Phase

In this subsection, we will discuss the principle of key share transfer in detail and propose a novel transfer mechanism to compute new key shares randomly while not exposing the secret key S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK.

The new set of decryptors. In every new round (assuming the Œ≥ùõæ\gamma-th round, Œ≥>1ùõæ1\gamma\textgreater 1), a new set of decryptors needs to be re-selected. Specifically, the server and all clients in [N]delimited-[]ùëÅ[N] compute D0n‚Äãe‚Äãw‚ÜêC‚ÄãH‚ÄãO‚ÄãO‚ÄãS‚ÄãE‚ÄãS‚ÄãE‚ÄãT‚Äã(v,Œ≥,L,N)‚Üêsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§ùê∂ùêªùëÇùëÇùëÜùê∏ùëÜùê∏ùëáùë£ùõæùêøùëÅD_{0}^{new}\leftarrow CHOOSESET(v,\gamma,L,N). In this subsection, we denote the newly selected decryptor set as D0n‚Äãe‚Äãwsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§D_{0}^{new}. The previous decryptors in D3subscriptùê∑3D_{3} need to transfer S‚ÄãK‚Ä≤‚ÄãsùëÜsuperscriptùêæ‚Ä≤ùë†SK^{\prime}s share to the new set D0n‚Äãe‚Äãwsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§D_{0}^{new}. It is worth noting that, based on Appendix B, each j‚ààD3\D4ùëó\subscriptùê∑3subscriptùê∑4j\in{D_{3}\backslash D_{4}} can obtain one share of s‚Ä≤superscriptùë†‚Ä≤s^{\prime} and each client i‚ààD4ùëñsubscriptùê∑4i\in{D_{4}} not only can obtain one share si‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùëñs^{\prime}_{i} but also hold a component of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK, due to s‚Ä≤=‚àëi‚ààD4sisuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤subscriptùëñsubscriptùê∑4subscriptùë†ùëñs^{\prime}=\sum_{i\in D_{4}}s_{i}. Therefore, we need to have an essential discussion in the following content, which includes: (1) What is the relationship between {si}i‚ààD4subscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñùëñsubscriptùê∑4\{s_{i}\}_{i\in D_{4}} and {sj‚Ä≤}j‚ààD3subscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùëóùëósubscriptùê∑3\{s^{\prime}_{j}\}_{j\in D_{3}}? (2) In order to recalculate S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK shares for decryptors in D0n‚Äãe‚Äãwsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§D_{0}^{new} (unlinkability with the previous round of shares) and ultimately achieve the reuse of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK, which of {si}i‚ààD4subscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñùëñsubscriptùê∑4\{s_{i}\}_{i\in D_{4}} and {sj‚Ä≤}j‚ààD3subscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùëóùëósubscriptùê∑3\{s^{\prime}_{j}\}_{j\in D_{3}} should we choose as the calculation objects for secret key transfer phase?

Discussions. We will have the following necessary discussions: (1) Discussion about the relationship between the shares and components of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK; (2) Discussion about the calculation objects for secret key transfer. We present specific discussion details in Appendix D.

Our scheme. From the above content, we can demonstrate that it is inappropriate to choose {sj‚Ä≤}j‚ààD3subscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùëóùëósubscriptùê∑3\{s^{\prime}_{j}\}_{j\in D_{3}} as the calculation object. Therefore, we propose a novel secret key transfer mechanism for components {si}i‚ààD4subscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñùëñsubscriptùê∑4\{s_{i}\}_{i\in D_{4}}. Before introducing the proposed scheme, we emphasize the following items: (1) S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK is a fixed value in the multi-round, calculated by S‚ÄãK=‚àëi‚ààD4siùëÜùêæsubscriptùëñsubscriptùê∑4subscriptùë†ùëñSK=\sum_{i\in D_{4}}s_{i} in the initial round. (2) The ultimate purpose of the proposed secret sharing mechanism is to ensure that the decryptors have a random share of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK for each round (The share is utilized in the reconstruction process).

The proposed scheme is fully presented in Figure 2. Here, we focus on the polynomial construction method (taking the parameter interaction between decryptors as an example, which can also be used between the server and decryptors) and depict the transfer procedure of S‚ÄãK‚Ä≤‚ÄãsùëÜsuperscriptùêæ‚Ä≤ùë†SK^{\prime}s shares in Figure 3.

4 Security and Privacy Analysis

In this section, we formally prove the security and privacy protection properties of our scheme. It should be noted that several security analyses have been conducted in [9] (such as graph connectivity); we mainly focus on conducting the safety analysis around the proposed share transfer mechanism, including several critical phases and operations. Besides, we also analyze the security of our scheme regarding gradient privacy and identity privacy. The details are as follows:

4.1 Security of Setup Phase

As described in Section 2.1, the threshold requirement claims that the upper bounds of dropout and corruption satisfy Œ¥Dt+Œ∑Dt<1/3subscriptùõøsubscriptùê∑ùë°subscriptùúÇsubscriptùê∑ùë°13\delta_{D_{t}}+\eta_{D_{t}}<1/3, which is emphasized in the DKG algorithm involved in the setup phase. Based on this upper bound setting, we can give the following theorem and discuss its justification.

Theorem 1.

The setup phase is secure, which can effectively prevent corrupted clients or the curious server from disclosing the reusable system secret key S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK.

Proof.

As shown in the final results in Section 3.2, the decryptors in D3subscriptùê∑3D_{3} can obtain the shares of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK, {sj‚Ä≤}j‚ààD3subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùë†ùëó‚Ä≤ùëósubscriptùê∑3\{s_{j}^{\prime}\}_{j\in D_{3}}, which can be utilized in the reconstruction process; the decryptors in D4subscriptùê∑4D_{4} additionally obtain components of the S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK, {si}i‚ààD4subscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñùëñsubscriptùê∑4\{s_{i}\}_{i\in D_{4}}, and S‚ÄãK=‚àëi‚ààD4siùëÜùêæsubscriptùëñsubscriptùê∑4subscriptùë†ùëñSK=\sum_{i\in D_{4}}s_{i}. Therefore, the adversaries have the following two ways to derive the S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK.

  • ‚Ä¢

    The adversaries collect enough shares from LùêøL decryptors (L=3‚Äãl+1)ùêø3ùëô1(L=3l+1) and calculate the secret key S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK by constructing a Lagrangian interpolation polynomial (as described in Appendix B, this polynomial has a unique constant term, which is the secret key S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK to be found).

  • ‚Ä¢

    The adversaries calculate the secret key S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK by collecting all components {si}i‚ààD4subscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñùëñsubscriptùê∑4\{s_{i}\}_{i\in D_{4}}.

However, as described in Appendix B, the DKG protocol enables the highest degree of the polynomial to be lùëôl when initiating S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK and calculating shares. Further, even considering the extreme case where 1/3131/3 decryptors are corrupted, the polynomial reconstruction condition is also not satisfied. Likewise, under |D4|‚â•2‚Äãl+1subscriptùê∑42ùëô1|D_{4}|\geq 2l+1, the probability of all decryptors being corrupted in D4subscriptùê∑4D_{4} is almost negligible. In addition, under the communication model defined in Section 2.2, the curious server cannot obtain any information regarding shares or components of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK. Therefore, if Œ¥Dt+Œ∑Dt<1/3subscriptùõøsubscriptùê∑ùë°subscriptùúÇsubscriptùê∑ùë°13\delta_{D_{t}}+\eta_{D_{t}}<1/3, our scheme can execute the setup phase securely. ‚àé

4.2 Security of Authentication Process

As described in Section 3.3, the server needs to perform the authentication process to verify the clients uploading the gradient. In this subsection, we conduct a detailed correctness analysis for the proposed authentication algorithm, discuss the zero-knowledge proof properties, and demonstrate privacy protection during the authentication process.

Theorem 2.

The server is able to perform correct calculations based on the prescribed authentication algorithm.

Proof.

As shown in Section 3.3, after receiving A‚Äãu‚Äãt‚Äãh={P‚ÄãI‚ÄãDi,Ri,p‚Äãs‚Äãki,c‚Äãp‚Äãki,t,t‚Äãsi,Œî‚ÄãTi,œÉ~i}ùê¥ùë¢ùë°‚ÑéùëÉùêºsubscriptùê∑ùëñsubscriptùëÖùëñùëùùë†subscriptùëòùëñùëêùëùsubscriptùëòùëñùë°ùë°subscriptùë†ùëñŒîsubscriptùëáùëñsubscript~ùúéùëñAuth=\{PID_{i},R_{i},psk_{i},cpk_{i},t,ts_{i},\Delta T_{i},\widetilde{\sigma}_{i}\} from Œ∫ùúÖ\kappa clients, the server implements the batch-authentication. Theorem 3.

The proposed authentication scheme is a non-interactive zero-knowledge proof on prover‚Äôs knowledge {s‚ÄãkŒ±,s‚ÄãkŒ≤}ùë†superscriptùëòùõºùë†superscriptùëòùõΩ\{sk^{\alpha},sk^{\beta}\}.

Proof.

From the lemmas presented in Appendix G.2, the proof of the theorem shows that the proposed authentication scheme satisfies the basic property: 1) completeness, 2) soundness, and 3) zero-knowledge. ‚àé

Theorem 4.

Our scheme is able to provide privacy-preserving properties, e.g., anonymity.

Proof.

Benefiting from the proposed authentication mechanism, we can prove that our scheme can provide reliable privacy preservation from identity anonymity, which is detailed in G.3 of Appendix G. ‚àé

Theorem 5.

Our scheme is able to resist various attacks, such as impersonation attacks, replay attacks.

Proof.

Our proposal can enable the server to authenticate clients effectively in the presence of various attacks, which is detailed in G.3 of Appendix G. ‚àé

4.3 Security of Reconstruction Process

As described in Section 3.3, to ensure that the reconstruction process is successful, at least 2‚Äãl+12ùëô12l+1 honest decryptors are required to reach an agreement. This requirement can be transformed into an assertion that the scheme can tolerate up to lùëôl abnormal clients (dropout or corruption). We first analyze the necessity of this requirement. We need to consider two dropout situations that need to be tolerated: (1) The decryptors do not have the share of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK (dropout fraction is Œ¥Dsubscriptùõøùê∑\delta_{D}), which only occurs in the aggregation round before performing the share transfer mechanism; (2) Only dropped during a particular round (dropout fraction is Œ¥D‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùõøùê∑‚Ä≤\delta_{D}^{\prime}), which occurs in any aggregation round. It should be noted that the dropouts can be treated as corrupt parties who have no response to server requests because corrupted clients can also perform unresponsive operations. Once there are no less than l+1ùëô1l+1 unresponsive or corrupted clients, the real gradient of this round may be leaked with a high probability, and the system must interrupt the aggregation process of this round in this situation. Therefore, the maximum fraction of abnormal decryptors that the scheme can tolerate needs to satisfy Œ¥D+Œ¥D‚Ä≤+Œ∑D<1/3subscriptùõøùê∑superscriptsubscriptùõøùê∑‚Ä≤subscriptùúÇùê∑13\delta_{D}+\delta_{D}^{\prime}+\eta_{D}\textless 1/3, which ensures that the reconstruction process can always be executed successfully. Based on the above inequality, we give the following theorem and proof.

Theorem 6.

The reconstruction process is secure and has dropout resilience. Meanwhile, our scheme can also prevent the curious server from recovering the real gradient of clients beyond timeout.

Proof.

Firstly, as mentioned in Section 3.3, masked gradient information that the server can receive contains two critical encryption parts: cmsubscriptùëêùëöc_{m} and (c0,c1)subscriptùëê0subscriptùëê1(c_{0},c_{1}). Therefore, it is explicit for adversaries to pursue the following two fundamental goals to achieve self-empowerment to extract the real gradient information uploaded by any regular client.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Decrypt a sufficient amount of ciphertext cmsubscriptùëêùëöc_{m} and finally calculate mi,tsubscriptùëöùëñùë°m_{i,t}.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Decrypt a sufficient amount of ciphertext (c0,c1)subscriptùëê0subscriptùëê1(c_{0},c_{1}) and finally calculate hi,tsubscript‚Ñéùëñùë°h_{i,t}.

Since L=3‚Äãl+1ùêø3ùëô1L=3l+1 and Œ¥D+Œ¥D‚Ä≤+Œ∑D<1/3subscriptùõøùê∑superscriptsubscriptùõøùê∑‚Ä≤subscriptùúÇùê∑13\delta_{D}+\delta_{D}^{\prime}+\eta_{D}\textless 1/3, there are at most lùëôl abnormal clients. Thus, based on lùëôl partial decryption results, the adversaries cannot construct a polynomial with the highest degree lùëôl to calculate mi,tsubscriptùëöùëñùë°m_{i,t} or decrypt hi,j,tsubscript‚Ñéùëñùëóùë°h_{i,j,t}. The system can prevent corrupted clients from stealing the real gradient information through collusion.

Besides, the real gradient of clients beyond timeout cannot be leaked either because these clients can be re-selected to participate in other rounds of aggregation processes. Consider a coincidental situation where the neighbors of client iùëñi beyond timeout are normal in the tùë°t-th round. In this case, the server will unintentionally recover the PRG seed {hi,j,t}j‚ààAt‚Äã(i)subscriptsubscript‚Ñéùëñùëóùë°ùëósubscriptùê¥ùë°ùëñ\{h_{i,j,t}\}_{j\in A_{t}(i)} of this client with the assistance of the reconstruction procedure, thereby obtaining {P‚ÄãR‚ÄãG‚Äã(hi,j,t)}ùëÉùëÖùê∫subscript‚Ñéùëñùëóùë°\{PRG(h_{i,j,t})\}. Thus, the curious server can secretly calculate the real gradient by x‚Üíi,t=V‚Äãei‚àí‚àëj‚ààAt‚Äã(i)¬±P‚ÄãR‚ÄãG‚Äã(hi,j,t)‚àíP‚ÄãR‚ÄãG‚Äã(mi,t)subscript‚Üíùë•ùëñùë°plus-or-minusùëâsubscriptùëíùëñsubscriptùëósubscriptùê¥ùë°ùëñùëÉùëÖùê∫subscript‚Ñéùëñùëóùë°ùëÉùëÖùê∫subscriptùëöùëñùë°\overrightarrow{x}_{i,t}=Ve_{i}-\sum_{j\in A_{t}(i)}\pm PRG(h_{i,j,t})-PRG(m_{i,t}), as long as it decrypts mi,tsubscriptùëöùëñùë°m_{i,t} with the pre-known secret key S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK. Fortunately, based on the demonstrations in Section 4.1, the curious server cannot obtain any information about the secret key S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK. Similarly, during the reconstruction procedure, our scheme allows decryptors to upload partial decryption results {c0sd‚Ä≤}d‚ààD3subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëê0superscriptsubscriptùë†ùëë‚Ä≤ùëësubscriptùê∑3\{c_{0}^{s_{d}^{\prime}}\}_{d\in D_{3}}, but neither the adversary nor the server can derive additional shares of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK from partial decryption results by breaking the DDH assumption. Therefore, our scheme can prevent the server from obtaining the secret key S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK and disclosing any client‚Äôs real gradient information.

Finally, the maximum fraction condition of abnormal decryptors allows reconstruction to be operated typically as long as at least 2‚Äãl+12ùëô12l+1 online honest decryptors can reach an agreement, ensuring dropout resilience during the reconstruction procedure. Thus, if Œ¥D+Œ¥D‚Ä≤+Œ∑D<1/3subscriptùõøùê∑superscriptsubscriptùõøùê∑‚Ä≤subscriptùúÇùê∑13\delta_{D}+\delta_{D}^{\prime}+\eta_{D}\textless 1/3, under the communication model defined in Section 2.2, our scheme can perform the reconstruction process securely. ‚àé

4.4 Correctness of Transfer Phase

As described in Section 3.4, we propose a novel share transfer mechanism to realize the transfer phase. Therefore, Proof of security for the transfer phase can be divided into two parts: computation of the new component set and computation of new share. The details are as follows:

Theorem 7.

The transfer phase can be performed correctly with the proposed secret key transfer mechanism.

Proof.

Firstly, we prove the correctness of the new component computation. 4.5 Security of Transfer Phase

Similar to Section 4.4, in this subsection, we demonstrate the security of the transfer phase around the following two main steps: computation of the new component set and computation of new share. There are three main types of adversaries: curious servers, corrupted regular clients, and corrupted decryptors. The main goal of the adversaries is to steal/crack the secret key S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK when performing the transfer phase. We give the following lemmas and proofs.

Lemma 1.

Our scheme can effectively resist the curious server or corrupt regular clients calculating secret key S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK during the transfer phase.

Proof.

Under the communication model defined in Section 2.2, the curious server cannot obtain any information regarding shares or components of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK during the transfer phase. Besides, it is infeasible for regular clients to derive the secret key S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK using P‚ÄãKùëÉùêæPK by breaking the DLP assumption. Thus, the transfer phase can be performed securely, ensuring that the secret key S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK cannot be derived by the server or corrupted regular clients. ‚àé

Lemma 2.

Our scheme can effectively resist corrupted decryptors calculating secret key S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK during the transfer phase.

Proof.

As described in Section 2.1, the threshold requirement claims that the upper bound of dropout and corruption satisfy Œ¥Dt+Œ∑Dt<1/3subscriptùõøsubscriptùê∑ùë°subscriptùúÇsubscriptùê∑ùë°13\delta_{D_{t}}+\eta_{D_{t}}<1/3, which is also emphasized in the transfer phase, especially for decryptors in D0n‚Äãe‚Äãwsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§D_{0}^{new} (|D0n‚Äãe‚Äãw|=Lsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§ùêø|D_{0}^{new}|=L).

In the computation process of the new component set, each decryptor i‚ààD4ùëñsubscriptùê∑4i\in D_{4} needs to calculate the parameter set {Œ≤i,df,si,d}superscriptsubscriptùõΩùëñùëëùëìsubscriptùë†ùëñùëë\{\beta_{i,d}^{f},s_{i,d}\} for each decryptor d‚ààD0n‚Äãe‚Äãwùëësuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§d\in D_{0}^{new}. Therefore, as described in Section 3.4, the adversaries need to collect all parameters {si,d}d‚ààD0n‚Äãe‚Äãw,i‚ààD4subscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñùëëformulae-sequenceùëësuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§ùëñsubscriptùê∑4\{s_{i,d}\}_{{d\in D_{0}^{new}},{i\in D_{4}}} to reconstruct polynomial function family {fi‚Äã(x)=ci,0+ci,1‚Äãx+‚ãØ+ci,L‚àí1‚ÄãxL‚àí1}i‚ààD4subscriptsubscriptùëìùëñùë•subscriptùëêùëñ0subscriptùëêùëñ1ùë•‚ãØsubscriptùëêùëñùêø1superscriptùë•ùêø1ùëñsubscriptùê∑4\{f_{i}(x)=c_{i,0}+c_{i,1}x+\cdots+c_{i,L-1}x^{L-1}\}_{i\in D_{4}} and calculate component set {si}i‚ààD4subscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñùëñsubscriptùê∑4\{s_{i}\}_{i\in D_{4}} by fi‚Äã(x)|x=0evaluated-atsubscriptùëìùëñùë•ùë•0f_{i}(x)|_{x=0}. Thus, our scheme can achieve a secure transfer phase while ensuring that the secret key is not disclosed or derived. ‚àé

Lemma 3.

Our scheme can effectively achieve forward/backward security of share computation and prevent adversaries from deriving S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK from using past shares.

Proof.

As described in Section 3.4, in each round, any client d‚ààD0n‚Äãe‚Äãwùëësuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§d\in D_{0}^{new} computes the new share of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK: sd‚Ä≤=‚àëj‚ààD0n‚Äãe‚Äãwsj,d‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùë†ùëë‚Ä≤subscriptùëósuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§superscriptsubscriptùë†ùëóùëë‚Ä≤s_{d}^{\prime}=\sum_{j\in D_{0}^{new}}s_{j,d}^{\prime}.

sd‚Ä≤=‚àëj‚ààD0n‚Äãe‚Äãwsjn‚Äãe‚Äãw+(‚àëj‚ààD0n‚Äãe‚ÄãwŒ≥1,j‚Ä≤)‚ãÖd+‚ãØ+(‚àëj‚ààD0n‚Äãe‚ÄãwŒ≥l,j‚Ä≤)‚ãÖdl.superscriptsubscriptùë†ùëë‚Ä≤subscriptùëósuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§superscriptsubscriptùë†ùëóùëõùëíùë§‚ãÖsubscriptùëósuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§superscriptsubscriptùõæ1ùëó‚Ä≤ùëë‚ãØ‚ãÖsubscriptùëósuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§superscriptsubscriptùõæùëôùëó‚Ä≤superscriptùëëùëôs_{d}^{\prime}=\sum_{j\in D_{0}^{new}}s_{j}^{new}+(\sum_{j\in D_{0}^{new}}\gamma_{1,j}^{\prime})\cdot d+\cdots+(\sum_{j\in D_{0}^{new}}\gamma_{l,j}^{\prime})\cdot d^{l}. (15)

What needs to be emphasized is that the polynomial coefficients set {Œ≥1,j‚Ä≤,Œ≥2,j‚Ä≤,‚ãØ,Œ≥l,j‚Ä≤}j‚ààD0n‚Äãe‚Äãwsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùõæ1ùëó‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùõæ2ùëó‚Ä≤‚ãØsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëôùëó‚Ä≤ùëósuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§\{\gamma_{1,j}^{\prime},\gamma_{2,j}^{\prime},\cdots,\gamma_{l,j}^{\prime}\}_{j\in D_{0}^{new}} that makes up the calculation of sd‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùë†ùëë‚Ä≤s_{d}^{\prime} is randomly generated by clients in D0n‚Äãe‚Äãwsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§D_{0}^{new}. Therefore, the share applied to a particular round is one-time and random, and the adversary cannot learn the forward/backward knowledge regarding the share‚Äôs computation from this random field. Besides, our proposal utilizes the redistribution of secret key components to assist in completing the transfer phase for secret key shares in each round, which makes the shares from the previous round not directly involved in calculating the share transfer phase, blocking the connection between shares.

Another thing to note is that the random generation of coefficients results in the polynomial function used to calculate shares being unique in each round. Therefore, based on the reconstruction algorithm in the secret sharing mechanism, i.e., a polynomial function can only be reconstructed by the shares produced by this polynomial function, the client or adversary cannot use the shares of different rounds (including past shares) to reconstruct S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK. ‚àé

5 Evaluation

This section focuses on evaluating the performance of our scheme, especially the end-to-end completion costs (mainly involving communication and computation operations) between clients and the server in the multi-round aggregation process. More concretely, in order to fully highlight the superiority of our scheme, we would emphatically answer the following issues with the assistance of the experiment:

  • ‚Ä¢

    How much cost (computation and communication) is incurred at the server and clients in our scheme when completing single or multiple rounds of aggregation?

  • ‚Ä¢

    What is the accuracy and time cost of the proposed scheme under different data sets? Moreover, is it superior to the state-of-the-art schemes?333Although the proposed share transfer mechanism enables Chu-ko-nu to have better reliability and practicality, the more complex structure also leads to additional costs of calculation and communication. We also mentioned it in Section 7. Therefore, it is undeniable that under the same measurement conditions, the overall costs of our scheme would be higher than Flamingo.

5.1 Experimental Setup

To accurately evaluate the performance of the proposed scheme, we utilize Python to construct the experiment on a PC machine with a 3.60 GHz Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-12700K processor and 32 GB RAM. Regarding specific parameter settings, we use AES-128 to implement authenticated encryption and ECDSA over curve P-256 to compute the signature. Besides, we set that the total clients N=103ùëÅsuperscript103N=10^{3}, and the number of clients participating in aggregation at tùë°t round is |St|=128subscriptùëÜùë°128|S_{t}|=128 (analogous to [9], we set each client iùëñi needs 414141 neighbors).

In the following contexts, we first analyze the computation and communication costs when completing single or multiple rounds of aggregation. Besides, in order to highlight the superiority, we compare the proposed scheme with VerSA [22] and Bell‚Äôs scheme[5], which are state-of-the-art schemes for efficient cross-device aggregation schemes (VerSA is conducted with a complete graph, and each client iùëñi needs 868686 neighbors in Bell‚Äôs scheme based on the parameter settings in [5] when total clients N=103ùëÅsuperscript103N=10^{3}). Moreover, we run Network Simulator 2 to measure communication latency for the multi-round aggregation process. Finally, with different datasets, we perform several complete FL processes to observe the accuracy and total time cost of the proposed scheme.

5.2 Secure Aggregation Costs

In the following contexts, we focus on the computation and communication costs incurred in a one-round aggregation, which are the dominant factors affecting the overall aggregation costs. Besides, in order to more accurately quantify communication costs, we set 256-bit elements in the multiplicative cyclic group ùîæùîæ\mathbb{G}, 32-bit elements in ‚Ñ§qsubscript‚Ñ§ùëû\mathbb{Z}_{q}. In terms of the decryptor and secret reconstruction process, we set the number of decryptors L=60ùêø60L=60 and threshold value l=20ùëô20l=20.

Communication costs. As shown in Figure 4, we first demonstrate the communication costs for each scheme. Three items should be noted in advance: (1) In the comparison of communication costs, we focus on comparing the additional information required for the interaction between the server and clients in each round of aggregation rather than repeating the comparison for some necessary uploaded data, such as masked gradients, updated models (as the communication cost caused by these data is almost equal for each scheme); (2) We focus on considering phases that are necessary to repeat in multi-round aggregation. Therefore, we ignore inessential or unrepresentative costs, such as running the Setup phase in the VerSA scheme, which is a one-time operation that exists throughout the aggregation process; (3) In order to more directly present the communication costs of each phase, we re-summarize each scheme into three steps: Key Distribution, Report, and Reconstruction. In the compared schemes, Advertising Key and Sharing Key are reclassified as Key Distribution setup; Masking Input and Unmasking Input are defined as Report and Reconstruction setup, respectively. Besides, it should be noted that, in our scheme, the analysis of communication costs in Cross check setup is classified in Report step.

As shown in Figure 4(a), our scheme has slightly lower communication costs in the key distribution phase than other schemes (even if the communication cost is only incurred between decryptors and the server, not all regular clients). That‚Äôs because the adoption of VSS and complain-disqualify mechanism still results in high data communication requirements, especially for the transmission of commitments {Ak}k=0lsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùê¥ùëòùëò0ùëô\{A_{k}\}_{k=0}^{l} and {Ck}k=0lsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëòùëò0ùëô\{C_{k}\}_{k=0}^{l}. Fortunately, the key distribution operation only needs to be performed in a single-round aggregation process. Specifically, benefiting from the proposed share transfer mechanism, in multiple rounds of aggregation, any member of different decryptor sets can obtain a random secret share of the same private key S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK (without violating the privacy of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK), and the server can perform the secret reconstruction process with l+1ùëô1l+1 arbitrary secret shares. Therefore, as shown in Figure 4(b), this key distribution phase does not need to be repeated in subsequent aggregation rounds, which makes that the communication costs of our scheme are at least lower 6.8√ó\times (i.e., better) than other schemes per round.

Figure 4(c) and 4(d) respectively present the communication costs of the report phase and reconstruction phase in the case of 10%percent1010\% clients dropout (or timeout). More concretely, Figure 4(c) presents the communication costs of the report phase. It is evident that the communication cost of our scheme is higher than that of other schemes. That is because, in our scheme, the client needs to upload many symmetric/asymmetric encrypted fields, while the compared schemes do not require performing this operation; meanwhile, the server also needs to execute the cross-check procedure, which results in additional communication costs. It is worth mentioning that, for our scheme, a portion of the client communication cost is only generated by decryptors rather than all clients participating in the round. But, for a more concise representation, we make a compromise by not distinguishing between the communication costs generated by different types of clients. Figure 4(d) presents the communication costs in the reconstruction phase. For our scheme, the client communication cost is only generated by decryptors. In addition, in order to support the verifiability of aggregated results, the VerSA scheme requires sending validation fields z¬Ø¬Øùëß\overline{z} to clients, which incurs additional communication costs. Therefore, at this phase, the communication cost of VerSA is higher than that of other schemes.

Finally, Figure 4(e) and 4(f) present the total communication costs in the single- and multi-round aggregation process, respectively. In the single-round aggregation process, limited by communication requirements in the key distribution and report phase, our scheme has a higher overall communication cost than other schemes. By contrast, benefiting from the proposed share transfer mechanism, in the multi-round aggregation process, our scheme can ease the overall communication burden by at least 44.97%percent44.9744.97\% compared to other schemes in each round.

Computation costs.

Figure 5 presents the computation costs for each scheme. More concretely, as shown in Figure 5(a), we measure the computation costs of the client and server in a single round aggregation, respectively. It is evident that our scheme is significantly more costly than other schemes, mainly because of the additional encryption and exponential operations in the key distribution phase. Moreover, from Figure 5(a), a large proportion of the computation costs during the single-round aggregation process are caused by the clients. This unaffordable computation cost is a major barrier to making multi-round secure aggregation. Fortunately, the proposed share transfer mechanism can effectively ease the computation effort of clients by freeing participants from the requirement to repeat the share transfer phase in subsequent rounds. Figure 5(b) presents computation costs in the multi-round aggregation process. Compared to Figure 5(a), benefiting from the share transfer mechanism, the computation costs are about 6.6√ó6.6\times lower (i.e., better).

It is worth noting that the total computation cost of our scheme is still slightly higher than other schemes. However, due to the dominant effect of communication latency, these additional computational costs do not cause a large impact on the overall multi-round aggregation process (the overall cost analysis will be presented explicitly in Section 5.3).

5.3 Performance Analysis

In this section, we implement the model training and evaluate its performance. More concretely, we measure and compare the model training accuracy and total running time of three schemes under different datasets. The training process still evolves from FedAvg[20], where each client trains local data in several iterations and obtains computed weights, which are then aggregated by the server to update the global model. The experiment setup and analysis details are as follows:

5.3.1 Setting of Dataset

We implement three datasets and look into how our scheme achieves superior performance compared to state-of-the-art schemes. Our experiments are conducted with a Nvidia 3090 graphics card and 24GB memory in the PyTorch environment. MNIST, CIFAR10, and GTSRB are selected as the primary datasets. The characteristics of the above three datasets are summarized in Table 1.

5.3.2 Setting of the Neural Network

To achieve the expected accuracy, each dataset is trained using a different neural network. For the MNIST dataset, we use a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) with three 3x3 convolution layers and a fully connected layer with 10 units. For the GTSRB dataset, we use a more complex convolutional neural network than we set for the MNIST dataset, with extra layers to build the model, raise the depth of learning in each iteration, and handle overfitting. For the CIFAR10 dataset, we used ResNet18, which consists of 17 convolution layers, rectified linear units, and 1 fully connected layer with 10 units.

5.3.3 Accuracy

We set different expected training rounds based on three datasets, 50, 500, and 100, for MNIST, CIFAR10, and GTSRB, respectively. Figure 6(a) ‚àºsimilar-to\sim (c) respectively present the growth trend of model accuracy as training rounds increase under MNIST, CIFAR10, and GTSRB datasets. It is worth mentioning that the essential gradient aggregation calculation methodologies (such as gradient accumulation) involved in each scheme have not been changed. Therefore, during the experiment, we observed that three schemes have achieved model convergence within the expected rounds. Meanwhile, the final accuracy and growth trend of the accuracy curve do not alter significantly during completing the expected rounds of training. Taking the GTSRB data set as an example, the accuracy is 98.51%percent98.5198.51\%, 96.68%percent96.6896.68\%, and 97.35%percent97.3597.35\%, respectively, for our scheme, VerSA, and Bell‚Äôs scheme.

5.3.4 Running Time

Initially, we analyze and compare the overall computation and communication costs with other schemes in Section 5.2. During the model training process, we comprehensively considered the two dominant factors mentioned above and explored their specific implications on the model training efficiency. In each round of training, we randomly select 128 clients as participants for this round of training and randomly divide the datasets equally among these 128 clients to serve as local training data. Figure 6(d) ‚àºsimilar-to\sim (f) present the overall running time under MNIST, CIFAR10, and GTSRB datasets, respectively. It is obvious that the overall running time shows a nearly linear upward trend as the number of training rounds increases. However, what needs special attention is that, under different datasets, our scheme enables the model to complete the training process for the desired number of rounds in the shortest time. Specifically, taking the MNIST dataset as an example, the running time of our scheme is reduced by about 63.11% compared to VerSA and about 21.02% compared to Bell‚Äôs scheme. Therefore, the data obtained from the experiment are significant evidence that our scheme has a superior performance for multi-round settings, which can effectively facilitate the heterogeneous federated learning process.

6 Related Work

6.1 Secure Aggregation for FL

Secure aggregation has received substantial research interest in achieving privacy-preserving FL. In this section, on the one hand, we mainly focus on discussing mask-based secure aggregation schemes applied in the FL scenarios. On the other hand, we also expound on the dilemma when extending traditional schemes to the multi-round aggregation setting.

The underlying principle of secure aggregation was proposed in [23], which supports clients‚Äô local gradient, before uploading them to the server, can be masked using the pairwise masks. The pairwise masks are calculated based on a pairwise secret key obtained through an agreement with other clients. The pairwise masks can automatically cancel out each other when the server accumulates received gradients. Meanwhile, to deal with the predicament of client dropout, the protocol also constructs a mask recovery mechanism. Although this protocol ensures no information leakage regarding clients‚Äô gradients during aggregation [1], it incurs unbearable communication overhead due to exchanging and reconstructing the pairwise keys, especially in large-scale FL systems.

More mask-optimized protocols are proposed to facilitate the secure aggregation process in the FL setting, aiming to realize privacy protection while improving aggregation efficiency. Specifically, some protocols attempt to accelerate model convergence by breaking communication bottlenecks, such as optimizing client selection [5, 24, 25, 26, 27, 28, 29]. For instance, Bell et al. [5] constructed kùëòk-regular graph for the FL network to replace the complete graph and achieve polylogarithmic communication per client. TurboAgg[25] divided nùëõn clients into n/l‚Äão‚Äãg‚Äãnùëõùëôùëúùëîùëõn/log\ n groups and implemented a multi-group circular aggregation operation. Likewise, a similar grouping structure was employed in [24]. However, these schemes require additional communication rounds between groups and sacrifice some resistance against colluding adversaries.

In addition, many researchers attempt to employ a lightweight or non-interactive key exchange protocol444Generally, this process is to calculate a seed using the key exchange protocol. This seed is used to calculate pairwise masks with the aid of the PRG function. Finally, the protocol utilizes the secret sharing mechanism to transfer shares of seed to the client‚Äôs neighbors. to complete the pairwise mask computation process to improve the aggregation scheme‚Äôs efficiency further. Mandal et al. [30] set up two non-colluding aided servers as cryptographic secret providers to assist each client in completing the pairwise mask calculation process in a non-interactive way. Zhang et al. [31] designed a lightweight two-server secure aggregation protocol based on secret-sharing, which achieved privacy protection and Byzantine robustness simultaneously. Eltaras et al. [32] utilized a single-mask technique to achieve a secure aggregation in the FL setting. Besides, this protocol also supports each client in verifying the aggregated result independently. Jiang et al. [33] utilized a lightweight homomorphic encryption algorithm to construct pairwise masks for gradients under the premise that the semi-trusted central server does not collude with any client. There are also some works [34, 35] trying to remove seed secret sharing operations between clients to improve aggregation efficiency. However, it should be noted that these schemes would incur a higher communication cost when handling dropouts, i.e., no support for lightweight dropout resilience.

The multi-round secure aggregation applied in FL is a valuable research topic because it has significant advantages in reducing training costs and lightweight dropout resilience. However, research on this topic is still relatively scarce, and only several state-of-the-art works [36, 9] are presented in the latest research. It is worth noting that, in the practical FL application, previous works are inappropriate to be directly extended to the multi-round aggregation setting [9] because they do not consider mitigating the potential privacy leakage and guaranteeing efficiency. Specifically, the clients participating in one specific aggregation round are randomly selected, but the necessary secrets need to support reusability across rounds of aggregation, e.g., the key pair used to compute pairwise masks. Therefore, when extending previous schemes to multi-round aggregation settings, the reuse of the key pair in the setup phase either needs one server with a security level of at least semi-trusted or a Public Key Infrastructure (PKI). If there is a semi-trusted server, the scheme also must require the adversary to be semi-honest to ensure that the key is not leaked, which is impractical. On the other hand, if there is a PKI, the fact that masks are one-time pads will also force the keys to be updated in each round.

6.2 Privacy Protection in FL

Although FL breaks the barrier of data sharing between clients/institutions, the transmission of gradients may leak the client‚Äôs identity information (e.g., real identity), especially when the client participates in the FL training process in a non-anonymous state. In order to tackle this issue, numerous researchers at home and abroad proposed hosts of privacy protection schemes applied in FL scenarios[13, 37, 38, 39, 15, 40, 41, 42, 43, 44, 45, 46]. For instance, to safely apply FL to autonomous driving, Li et al. [41] constructed privacy protection mechanisms for communications between entities with different credibility. Briefly, for the honest-but-curious server and malicious vehicles, the authors propose a traceable identity-based privacy-preserving scheme and a blockchain-based incentive mechanism. When the communication occurred between parties with non-credibility, authors utilized an interactive zero-knowledge proof to design an anonymous identity-based privacy-preserving scheme to protect identity privacy. However, this scheme requires multiple interactions during the verification of clients, which incurs additional communication overhead. Yuan et al. [13] proposed a privacy-enhanced and efficient authentication protocol for federated learning in Vehicular Ad-Hoc Networks (VANETs), which supports the client to participate in the federated learning training process anonymously and can accurately identify and eliminate malicious clients. To ensure local model integrity and achieve source authentication, Fan et al. [46] proposed a blockchain-based and lightweight anonymous FL identity authentication scheme. The scheme enables the server to perform batch authentication for clients with a lightweight digital signature algorithm. In addition, it also supports anonymous communication in the FL training process and malicious clients can be tracked by the trusted authority. Similarly, Yang et al. [43] utilized the ring signature to prevent adversaries from learning identity information of clients. Kanchan and Choi [44] proposed an efficient and privacy-preserving federated learning scheme based on group signatures and set up a group administrator responsible for tracing the real identities of malicious clients. For achieving privacy-preserving distributed learning, Jiang et al. [38] utilized a certificateless signature scheme to construct an anonymous and efficient authentication protocol. However, this scheme involves some complex cryptographic operations, such as bilinear pairing, affecting the efficiency of authentication. In short, at first glance, existing privacy-preserving FL schemes provide various properties (e.g., anonymity) for clients and mitigate the risk of identity information leakage. However, the complex cryptographic algorithm and execution mechanism still result in unaffordable computational and communication overhead. Therefore, these FL schemes have high limitations in the application, especially over some scenarios with high real-time requirements (e.g., VANET).

7 Conclusion

In this paper, we study and discuss the advantages and dilemmas regarding Flamingo in terms of practicality. Afterwards, we propose a reliable multi-round aggregation scheme (called Chu-ko-nu). By supplementing a redistribution process of secret key components (the sum of all components is the secret key), Chu-ko-nu can achieve more reliable share transfer process, and thus ensuring the reusability of the secret key. Based on this reusable secret key, Chu-ko-nu can efficiently perform consecutive aggregation in the following rounds. Moreover, Chu-ko-nu introduces a zero-knowledge proof-based authentication mechanism to enable the server to effectively verify the client while resisting various attacks and achieving privacy protection for identity information (e.g., supporting clients to participate in the training process anonymously). The experiment and security analysis show that our proposal can provide reliable security while ensuring low aggregation costs. However, it is worth noting that during the experiment, we found that although the applied share transfer mechanism is more reliable and practical, it requires more calculation steps, which incurs additional communication and calculation overhead. Therefore, we hope to optimize the proposed plan in future work while maintaining its high reliability and minimizing its execution costs as much as possible.

Appendix A: Cryptographic building blocks

In this section, we formally define some standard cryptographic primitives involved in our proposal.

Definition 1 (Pseudo-random generators, PRG). We define a PRG as a deterministic function that includes the specific algorithm:

  • ‚Ä¢

    P‚ÄãR‚ÄãG‚Äã(S~)‚ÜíRS~‚ÜíùëÉùëÖùê∫~ùëÜsubscriptùëÖ~ùëÜPRG(\widetilde{S})\rightarrow R_{\widetilde{S}}: input a random seed S‚àà{0,1}ŒªùëÜsuperscript01ùúÜS\in\{0,1\}^{\lambda} and output a longer string RS~subscriptùëÖ~ùëÜR_{\widetilde{S}}.

In practical, ŒªùúÜ\lambda is the computational security parameter, and the output RS~subscriptùëÖ~ùëÜR_{\widetilde{S}} cannot be distinguished from a random string at a computational level.

Definition 2 (Pseudo-random functions, PRF). We define a PRF as a family of deterministic functions: ùí¶√óùí≥‚Üíùí¥‚Üíùí¶ùí≥ùí¥\mathcal{K}\times\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathcal{Y}, which is indexed by a key in ùí¶ùí¶\mathcal{K} that maps an input in ùí≥ùí≥\mathcal{X} to an output in ùí¥ùí¥\mathcal{Y}. Besides, the indexed function is computationally indistinguishable from a truly random function from ùí≥ùí≥\mathcal{X} to ùí¥ùí¥\mathcal{Y}.

Definition 8 (Diffie-Hellman key exchange). Define a cyclic group ùîæùîæ\mathbb{G} with the generator gùëîg, order qùëûq. This key exchange protocol can output a secure shared secret for both parties to the key exchange (assuming a passive adversary). Its execution process can be described as follows:

  • 1)

    Alice samples a secret sA‚Üê$‚Ñ§qcurrency-dollar‚Üêsubscriptùë†ùê¥subscript‚Ñ§ùëûs_{A}\xleftarrow{\$}\mathbb{Z}_{q} and computes gsA‚ààùîæsuperscriptùëîsubscriptùë†ùê¥ùîæg^{s_{A}}\in\mathbb{G}.

  • 2)

    Bob samples a secret sB‚Üê$‚Ñ§qcurrency-dollar‚Üêsubscriptùë†ùêµsubscript‚Ñ§ùëûs_{B}\xleftarrow{\$}\mathbb{Z}_{q} and computes gsB‚ààùîæsuperscriptùëîsubscriptùë†ùêµùîæg^{s_{B}}\in\mathbb{G}.

  • 3)

    Alice and Bob exchange the public value gsAsuperscriptùëîsubscriptùë†ùê¥g^{s_{A}} and gsBsuperscriptùëîsubscriptùë†ùêµg^{s_{B}} and raise the received value to their secret, i.e., (gsB)sA=(gsA)sB=gsA‚ãÖsBsuperscriptsuperscriptùëîsubscriptùë†ùêµsubscriptùë†ùê¥superscriptsuperscriptùëîsubscriptùë†ùê¥subscriptùë†ùêµsuperscriptùëî‚ãÖsubscriptùë†ùê¥subscriptùë†ùêµ(g^{s_{B}})^{s_{A}}=(g^{s_{A}})^{s_{B}}=g^{{s_{A}}\cdot{s_{B}}}.

If DDH is hard, the shared secret gsA‚ãÖsBsuperscriptùëî‚ãÖsubscriptùë†ùê¥subscriptùë†ùêµg^{{s_{A}}\cdot{s_{B}}} is opaque to anyone except Alice and Bob.

Definition 10 (Elliptic Curve Discrete Logarithm Problem). Details of the ECDLP are as follows: Given an elliptic curve ùîºp‚Äã(a,b)subscriptùîºùëùùëéùëè\mathbb{E}_{p}(a,b) generated based on a finite field FpsubscriptùêπùëùF_{p}, and an additive group ùîæ~~ùîæ\widetilde{\mathbb{G}} containing the points in the elliptic curve. Selecting ‚àÄQ‚ààùîæ~for-allùëÑ~ùîæ\forall Q\in\widetilde{\mathbb{G}}, and satisfies Q=x‚ÄãPùëÑùë•ùëÉQ=xP, x‚àà‚Ñ§q‚àóùë•superscriptsubscript‚Ñ§ùëûx\in\mathbb{Z}_{q}^{*}. Definition 11 (Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman Problem). Definition 12 (Signature scheme). The signature scheme consists of the following specific algorithms:

  • ‚Ä¢

    S‚ÄãS.G‚Äãe‚Äãn‚Äã(1Œª)‚Üí(s‚Äãk,p‚Äãk)formulae-sequenceùëÜùëÜ‚Üíùê∫ùëíùëõsuperscript1ùúÜùë†ùëòùëùùëòSS.Gen(1^{\lambda})\rightarrow(sk,pk): output a pair of key (s‚Äãk,p‚Äãk)ùë†ùëòùëùùëò(sk,pk) based on ECC, satisfying p‚Äãk=s‚Äãk‚ãÖPùëùùëò‚ãÖùë†ùëòùëÉpk=sk\cdot P.

  • ‚Ä¢

    S‚ÄãS.S‚Äãi‚Äãg‚Äãn‚Äã(s‚Äãk,m)‚ÜíœÉformulae-sequenceùëÜùëÜ‚ÜíùëÜùëñùëîùëõùë†ùëòùëöùúéSS.Sign(sk,m)\rightarrow\sigma: input the key s‚Äãkùë†ùëòsk and message mùëöm, and output the signature œÉùúé\sigma.

Appendix D: Discussions about transfer phase

In this appendix, we have the following discussions about the transfer phase: (1) The relationship between the shares and components of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK; (2) The calculation objects for the secret key transfer phase.

D.1. Discussion about the relationship between the shares and components of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK.

Based on the description in Appendix B, the shares and components are eventually held by decryptors in D3subscriptùê∑3D_{3} and D4subscriptùê∑4D_{4}, respectively. Thus, we set this as the scope of discussion. Reviewing the share calculation process, we know that the shares of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK obtained by the decryptors in D3subscriptùê∑3D_{3} are calculated based on the components held by decryptors in D4subscriptùê∑4D_{4}. More specifically, the components sisubscriptùë†ùëñs_{i} are independently generated by decryptors i‚ààD4ùëñsubscriptùê∑4i\in D_{4}, and each decryptor generates the corresponding shares si,jsubscriptùë†ùëñùëós_{i,j} for decryptors j‚ààD3ùëósubscriptùê∑3j\in D_{3} based on the local component (note that si,jsubscriptùë†ùëñùëós_{i,j} is sisubscriptùë†ùëñs_{i}‚Äôs share, not S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK‚Äôs). Each decryptor j‚ààD3ùëósubscriptùê∑3j\in D_{3} can eventually obtain the share of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK by accumulating the received shares {si,j}i‚ààD3subscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñùëóùëñsubscriptùê∑3\{s_{i,j}\}_{i\in D_{3}}. It can be seen from this that components are the sources of share calculation for the S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK. Based on this relationship, we next need to discuss and analyze in detail which of the component and shares we should choose as the calculation objects in the secret key transfer phase.

D.2. Discussion about the selection of calculation objects for the secret key transfer phase.

Based on the description in Appendix C, the ultimate goal of the secret key transfer mechanism is that a part of decryptors in D0n‚Äãe‚Äãwsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§D_{0}^{new} can recalculate the shares of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK that meet the following conditions: There exists a coefficient set {Pd‚Äã(0)}d‚ààU~subscriptsubscriptùëÉùëë0ùëë~ùëà\{P_{d}(0)\}_{d\in\widetilde{U}} such that equation ‚àëd‚ààU~s^d‚Ä≤‚ÄãPd‚Äã(0)=S‚ÄãKsubscriptùëë~ùëàsubscriptsuperscript^ùë†‚Ä≤ùëësubscriptùëÉùëë0ùëÜùêæ\sum_{d\in\widetilde{U}}\hat{s}^{\prime}_{d}P_{d}(0)=SK holds, where U~~ùëà\widetilde{U} represents the set of decryptors participating in decrypting pairwise mask h‚Ñéh, and s^d‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscript^ùë†‚Ä≤ùëë\hat{s}^{\prime}_{d}, calculated by d‚ààD0n‚Äãe‚Äãwùëësuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§d\in D_{0}^{new}, is the new share of S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK. Therefore, there are two ways of idea for the calculation of s^d‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscript^ùë†‚Ä≤ùëë\hat{s}^{\prime}_{d}: (1) Calculate {s^d‚Ä≤}subscriptsuperscript^ùë†‚Ä≤ùëë\{\hat{s}^{\prime}_{d}\} for d‚ààD0n‚Äãe‚Äãwùëësuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§{d\in D_{0}^{new}} directly based on the current share set sd‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùëë{s}^{\prime}_{d}; (2) Recalculate the S‚ÄãKùëÜùêæSK component based on the current set {si}i‚ààD4subscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñùëñsubscriptùê∑4\{s_{i}\}_{i\in D_{4}}, then calculate the new shares {s^d‚Ä≤}subscriptsuperscript^ùë†‚Ä≤ùëë\{\hat{s}^{\prime}_{d}\} for d‚ààD0n‚Äãe‚Äãwùëësuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§{d\in D_{0}^{new}}.

The first idea can be analyzed through the following content. To achieve this, for each d‚ààD0n‚Äãe‚Äãwùëësuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§d\in D_{0}^{new}, it is necessary to calculate ‚àën=1n=|D3|œïn‚Äãe‚Äãwn‚Äã(d)‚ãÖŒ≤^j=‚àëj‚ààD3sj,d‚Ä≤‚ãÖŒ≤^jsuperscriptsubscriptùëõ1ùëõsubscriptùê∑3‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œïùëõùëíùë§ùëõùëësubscript^ùõΩùëósubscriptùëósubscriptùê∑3‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptùë†ùëóùëë‚Ä≤subscript^ùõΩùëó\sum_{n=1}^{n=|D_{3}|}\phi_{new}^{n}(d)\cdot\hat{\beta}_{j}=\sum_{j\in D_{3}}s_{j,d}^{\prime}\cdot\hat{\beta}_{j}. Therefore, we need to focus on discussing the computational feasibility of {Œ≤^j}j‚ààD3subscriptsubscript^ùõΩùëóùëósubscriptùê∑3\{\hat{\beta}_{j}\}_{j\in D_{3}}.

First, we have to note the origin of sj‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùë†ùëó‚Ä≤s_{j}^{\prime}: sj‚Ä≤=s‚Ä≤+Œ±1,f‚ãÖj+Œ±2,f‚ãÖj2+‚ãØ+Œ±l,f‚ãÖjlsuperscriptsubscriptùë†ùëó‚Ä≤superscriptùë†‚Ä≤‚ãÖsubscriptùõº1ùëìùëó‚ãÖsubscriptùõº2ùëìsuperscriptùëó2‚ãØ‚ãÖsubscriptùõºùëôùëìsuperscriptùëóùëôs_{j}^{\prime}=s^{\prime}+\alpha_{1,f}\cdot j+\alpha_{2,f}\cdot j^{2}+\cdots+\alpha_{l,f}\cdot j^{l}, which is a polynomial function of degree lùëôl. Based on the ideas provided in Appendix C, in order to achieve ‚àëj‚ààD3sj‚Ä≤‚ãÖŒ≤^j=s‚Ä≤subscriptùëósubscriptùê∑3‚ãÖsubscriptsuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤ùëósubscript^ùõΩùëósuperscriptùë†‚Ä≤\sum_{j\in D_{3}}{s}^{\prime}_{j}\cdot\hat{\beta}_{j}=s^{\prime}, only l+1ùëô1l+1 decryptors in D3subscriptùê∑3D_{3} can be selected per batch for each new decryptor d‚ààD0n‚Äãe‚Äãwùëësuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§{d\in D_{0}^{new}} to compute the corresponding coefficient, until the corresponding coefficients are calculated for all received |D‚Äã3|ùê∑3|D3| (|D‚Äã3|>l)ùê∑3ùëô(|D3|>l) shares {sj,d‚Ä≤}j‚ààD3subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùë†ùëóùëë‚Ä≤ùëósubscriptùê∑3\{s_{j,d}^{\prime}\}_{j\in D_{3}}. But there is a potential flaw here, that is, the decryptors in D0n‚Äãe‚Äãwsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§D_{0}^{new} cannot tacitly select the same decryptors in D3subscriptùê∑3D_{3} for calculation in each batch, especially decryptors are individuals who perform business independently. Because all decryptors in D0n‚Äãe‚Äãwsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§D_{0}^{new} can only achieve the correct construction of the corresponding coefficients through Lagrangian interpolation when the same l+1ùëô1l+1 decryptors in D3subscriptùê∑3D_{3} are selected simultaneously as objects to calculate parameter Œ≤^jsubscript^ùõΩùëó\hat{\beta}_{j} for each received sj,d‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùë†ùëóùëë‚Ä≤s_{j,d}^{\prime}. Specifically, there is a potential premise for the correct execution of the protocol, and it is necessary to ensure that the final share s^d‚Ä≤superscriptsubscript^ùë†ùëë‚Ä≤\hat{s}_{d}^{\prime} obtained by each decryptor can be expressed by the same one polynomial, in other words, to ensure the consistency of the coefficient set {Œ≥i,f}i=1i=lsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùõæùëñùëìùëñ1ùëñùëô\{\gamma_{i,f}\}_{i=1}^{i=l}. Thus, from the perspective of selection, which needs to be repeated at least lùëôl times for each decryptor in D3subscriptùê∑3D_{3} per round. This condition can only be achieved with a P~~ùëÉ\widetilde{P} probability (the details about probability P~~ùëÉ\widetilde{P} are shown in Appendix D.3). Therefore, it is not suitable for practical applications of federated learning.

In addition, it is also necessary to consider, i.e., can the decryptors in D0n‚Äãe‚Äãwsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§D_{0}^{new} complete the share transfer by specifying a specific calculation sequence with the assistance of the server? First, on the one hand, if the interaction between decryptors for share transfer is achieved with the assistance of timely forwarding by the server, the server cannot foresee the order of decryptors initiating interaction requests. It thus cannot determine the calculation sequence for decryptors in D0n‚Äãe‚Äãwsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§D_{0}^{new}. On the other hand, there is a high probability that the decryptors in D0n‚Äãe‚Äãwsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§D_{0}^{new} cannot construct an accurate and unified calculation sequence based on the order of received messages about shares because the process is asynchronous, and network delays will have a profound impact on the calculation sequences constructed by different decryptors. Second, suppose the share interaction between decryptors is achieved with the assistance of non-timely forwarding by the server, i.e., the server receives all the shares from decryptors in D3subscriptùê∑3D_{3} before forwarding and determines a unified calculation sequence locally. However, this method has high vulnerability and externality. Any abnormality caused by any risk, such as adversaries corrupting the server or communication delay, will cause decryptors in D0n‚Äãe‚Äãwsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§D_{0}^{new} to be unable to receive a unified calculation sequence (incomplete calculation sequence or any element in the sequence has changed), further affecting the aggregation process of the entire FL system.

Obviously, this calculation method has extremely low fault tolerance, which is attributed to the fact that this method makes the determination of the entire calculation sequence utterly dependent on the stability of the server and communication conditions, while the decryptors in D0n‚Äãe‚Äãwsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑0ùëõùëíùë§D_{0}^{new} lacks the computational autonomy it deserves for the determination of calculation sequence. Thus, the above factors should be considered in the construction of the share transfer mechanism.

D.3. Definition and calculation of probability P~~ùëÉ\widetilde{P}.

In Appendix D.2, we present two ways of the idea for the calculation of s^d‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscript^ùë†‚Ä≤ùëë{\hat{s}}^{\prime}_{d}. We define P~~ùëÉ\widetilde{P} as the probability that the first calculation method holds (i.e., the method (1) presented in D.2, this method is also chosen by Flamingo). We first define several necessary calculation symbols. The permutation and combination (choose kùëòk from nùëõn) are respectively represented as (nk)binomialùëõùëò\binom{n}{k} and Cnksuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëõùëòC_{n}^{k}. Set v~=Ll+1~ùë£ùêøùëô1\widetilde{v}=\frac{L}{l+1}. Based on the description in D.2, each decryptor d‚ààD3ùëësubscriptùê∑3d\in D_{3} needs to choose other lùëôl decryptors (assuming set Cdsubscriptùê∂ùëëC_{d} is composed of all lùëôl decryptors) as parameters for calculation, let the set Cd~={d}‚à™Cd~subscriptùê∂ùëëùëësubscriptùê∂ùëë\widetilde{C_{d}}=\{d\}\cup C_{d}. Similarly, the decryptor d‚Ä≤‚ààCdsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤subscriptùê∂ùëëd^{\prime}\in C_{d} repeats this operation, which needs to satisfy Cd‚Ä≤~=Cd~~subscriptùê∂superscriptùëë‚Ä≤~subscriptùê∂ùëë\widetilde{C_{d^{\prime}}}=\widetilde{C_{d}}. Considering the set C~~ùê∂\widetilde{C} contains various decryptors, we can calculate that the number of combinations that can make the calculation method (1) hold is NP~=(LL)/[(l+1l+1)v~‚ãÖ(v~v~)]subscriptùëÅ~ùëÉbinomialùêøùêødelimited-[]‚ãÖsuperscriptbinomialùëô1ùëô1~ùë£binomial~ùë£~ùë£N_{\widetilde{P}}={\binom{L}{L}}/\left[{{\binom{l+1}{l+1}}^{\widetilde{v}}\cdot{\binom{\widetilde{v}}{\widetilde{v}}}}\right]. However, it should be emphasized that the selection method for each decryptor in D3subscriptùê∑3D_{3} is independent. Therefore, the final probability calculation is P~=(1CL‚àí1l)L‚ãÖNP~~ùëÉ‚ãÖsuperscript1superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùêø1ùëôùêøsubscriptùëÅ~ùëÉ\widetilde{P}=(\frac{1}{C_{L-1}^{l}})^{L}\cdot N_{\widetilde{P}}.

Appendix E: Detailed protocol for each round

The detailed protocol for each round is presented in Figure 7. It should be noted that the Setup Phase is only executed in the first round, and the protocol follows some prescribed assumptions about Collection Phase from [9]. For example, client iùëñi participating in tùë°t-round aggregation can download public keys of its neighbors At‚Äã(i)subscriptùê¥ùë°ùëñA_{t}(i) from KMI, and clients can pre-fetch public keys used in the coming rounds.
