G.2. Properties of zero-knowledge proof

In this subsection, we prove that the proposed authentication scheme satisfies the basic properties: 1) completeness, 2) soundness, and 3) zero-knowledge. Besides, it should be noted that clients act as provers, while the verifier is the server.

Lemma 4.

The proposed protocol satisfies completeness, i.e., the prover can pass the verifier‚Äôs validation as long as the prover has the correct knowledge. Moreover, the prover can convince the verifier with a sufficient probability.

Proof.

We assume that client iùëñi is an honest prover in possession of the authentication parameters A‚Äãu‚Äãt‚Äãhùê¥ùë¢ùë°‚ÑéAuth. Therefore, as described in Section 3.3, client iùëñi can calculate the correct parameters {P‚ÄãI‚ÄãDi,Ri,p‚Äãs‚Äãki,c‚Äãp‚Äãki,t,t‚Äãsi,Œî‚ÄãTi,œÉ~i}ùëÉùêºsubscriptùê∑ùëñsubscriptùëÖùëñùëùùë†subscriptùëòùëñùëêùëùsubscriptùëòùëñùë°ùë°subscriptùë†ùëñŒîsubscriptùëáùëñsubscript~ùúéùëñ\{PID_{i},R_{i},psk_{i},cpk_{i},t,ts_{i},\Delta T_{i},\widetilde{\sigma}_{i}\}. Based on these parameters, the verifier can validate that client iùëñi has correct secret {c‚Äãs‚Äãki}ùëêùë†subscriptùëòùëñ\{csk_{i}\} through the equations: e‚Äã(UŒ±,P)‚Äã=?‚Äãe‚Äã(UŒ≤,m‚Äãp‚Äãk)ùëísuperscriptùëàùõºùëÉ?ùëísuperscriptùëàùõΩùëöùëùùëòe(U^{\alpha},P)\overset{?}{=}e(U^{\beta},mpk) and S‚Äã=?‚Äã‚àëj=1Œ∫Dj‚ãÖMj‚Ä≤‚ãÖs‚Äãs‚ÄãkùëÜ?superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùúÖ‚ãÖsubscriptùê∑ùëósuperscriptsubscriptùëÄùëó‚Ä≤ùë†ùë†ùëòS\overset{?}{=}\sum_{j=1}^{\kappa}D_{j}\cdot M_{j}^{\prime}\cdot ssk. The correctness analysis of the equations involved in the certification process is detailed in Section 4.2. ‚àé

Lemma 5.

The proposed authentication scheme satisfies soundness, i.e., the prover cannot pass the verifier‚Äôs validation as long as the prover does not have the correct knowledge. Moreover, the probability that the prover successfully deceives the verifier can be ignored.

Proof.

Lemma 6.

The proposed protocol satisfies zero-knowledge, i.e., the prover can prove that it has the corresponding correct knowledge without disclosing any extra information about the knowledge.

Proof.

In our proposal, secret {c‚Äãs‚Äãki}ùëêùë†subscriptùëòùëñ\{csk_{i}\} is masked in parameters Si=c‚Äãs‚Äãki‚ãÖMi‚ãÖs‚Äãp‚ÄãksubscriptùëÜùëñ‚ãÖùëêùë†subscriptùëòùëñsubscriptùëÄùëñùë†ùëùùëòS_{i}=csk_{i}\cdot M_{i}\cdot spk. It should be noted that this paper assumes that mathematical assumptions cannot be broken. Therefore, the verifier or adversary is unable to derive secret from existing knowledge (e.g., based on the ECDLP, the verifier cannot calculate c‚Äãs‚Äãkiùëêùë†subscriptùëòùëñcsk_{i}, even if the verifier already knows knowledge s‚Äãp‚Äãkùë†ùëùùëòspk and MisubscriptùëÄùëñ{M_{i}}). Obviously, the verifier does not learn any additional knowledge from parameters Si=c‚Äãs‚Äãki‚ãÖMi‚ãÖs‚Äãp‚ÄãksubscriptùëÜùëñ‚ãÖùëêùë†subscriptùëòùëñsubscriptùëÄùëñùë†ùëùùëòS_{i}=csk_{i}\cdot M_{i}\cdot spk, and the prover‚Äôs secret knowledge {c‚Äãs‚Äãki}ùëêùë†subscriptùëòùëñ\{csk_{i}\} is not leaked.‚àé

G.3. Privacy-preserving properties

In this subsection, we prove that our proposal can achieve reliable privacy preservation from identity anonymity. In addition, we also prove that our scheme is able to defend against common attacks, including impersonation attacks, forgery attacks, tampering attacks, and replay attacks.

Lemma 7.

The proposed protocol can achieve reliable privacy preservation from identity anonymity.

Proof.

As described in Section 3.2, the clients have to be registered before participating in the business of secure aggregation with anonymity. It is worth noting that we assume the RA responsible for executing the registration procedure is a trusted authority. Therefore, the adversaries only have two methods to obtain the client‚Äôs real identity I‚ÄãDùêºùê∑ID. First, the adversaries eavesdrop on private information in the transmission process. However, the client accomplishes registration and attains an anonymous identity via a secure communication channel or offline in our proposal. Second, the adversaries decode the plaintext from the ciphertext P‚ÄãI‚ÄãDùëÉùêºùê∑PID. However, based on the mathematical assumption described in Appendix A, the adversaries cannot break cryptographic primitives to obtain the real identity from P‚ÄãI‚ÄãDùëÉùêºùê∑PID. ‚àé

Lemma 8.

The proposed protocol is resistant to the impersonation attack.

Proof.

The adversary or malicious client FùêπF intends to utilize another client iùëñi‚Äôs anonymous identity P‚ÄãI‚ÄãDiùëÉùêºsubscriptùê∑ùëñPID_{i} to spoof the server. Since the parameter c‚Äãp‚Äãkiùëêùëùsubscriptùëòùëñcpk_{i} is a public field, we need to discuss whether the attacker applies this public field in the authentication message.

Firstly, if the attacker utilizes this public key in the latest authentication process (assume Œ±ùõº\alpha-th authentication process), then the parameter SiŒ±superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëñùõºS_{i}^{\alpha} corresponding to the public key must be calculated based on the prescribed authentication algorithm. However, based on the cryptographic assumptions of this paper, the attacker cannot infer the key information c‚Äãs‚Äãkiùëêùë†subscriptùëòùëñcsk_{i} from the known parameters MisubscriptùëÄùëñM_{i}, s‚Äãp‚Äãkùë†ùëùùëòspk, and SisubscriptùëÜùëñS_{i}. Therefore, the attacker cannot construct correct knowledge corresponding to the P‚ÄãI‚ÄãDiùëÉùêºsubscriptùê∑ùëñPID_{i} to complete the verification process of the equation S‚Äã=?‚Äã‚àëj=1kDj‚ãÖMj‚Ä≤ùëÜ?superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëò‚ãÖsubscriptùê∑ùëósuperscriptsubscriptùëÄùëó‚Ä≤S\overset{?}{=}\sum_{j=1}^{k}D_{j}\cdot M_{j}^{\prime}, and the details of this part of the proof have been shown in Appendix G.2.

Lemma 9.

The proposed protocol is resistant to the forgery attack and tampering attack.

Proof.

In the authentication process, the server receives parameters A‚Äãu‚Äãt‚Äãh={P‚ÄãI‚ÄãDi,Ri,p‚Äãs‚Äãki,c‚Äãp‚Äãki,t,t‚Äãsi,Œî‚ÄãTi,œÉ~i}ùê¥ùë¢ùë°‚ÑéùëÉùêºsubscriptùê∑ùëñsubscriptùëÖùëñùëùùë†subscriptùëòùëñùëêùëùsubscriptùëòùëñùë°ùë°subscriptùë†ùëñŒîsubscriptùëáùëñsubscript~ùúéùëñAuth=\{PID_{i},R_{i},psk_{i},cpk_{i},t,ts_{i},\Delta T_{i},\widetilde{\sigma}_{i}\} and verifies the equations: e‚Äã(UŒ±,P)‚Äã=?‚Äãe‚Äã(UŒ≤,m‚Äãp‚Äãk)ùëísuperscriptùëàùõºùëÉ?ùëísuperscriptùëàùõΩùëöùëùùëòe(U^{\alpha},P)\overset{?}{=}e(U^{\beta},mpk) and S‚Äã=?‚Äã‚àëj=1Œ∫Dj‚ãÖMj‚Ä≤‚ãÖs‚Äãs‚ÄãkùëÜ?superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùúÖ‚ãÖsubscriptùê∑ùëósuperscriptsubscriptùëÄùëó‚Ä≤ùë†ùë†ùëòS\overset{?}{=}\sum_{j=1}^{\kappa}D_{j}\cdot M_{j}^{\prime}\cdot ssk. Based on the analysis in Appendix G.1 and G.2, clients or the adversary cannot modify or forge authentication information to satisfy the calculation of the above two equations. Therefore, any forgery or tampering of parameter set A‚Äãu‚Äãt‚Äãhùê¥ùë¢ùë°‚ÑéAuth will not satisfy the correctness calculation of the prescribed authentication algorithm, and our proposal can effectively resist the forgery attack and tampering attack. ‚àé

Lemma 10.

The proposed protocol is resistant to the replay attack.

Proof.

In this type of attack, during the latest authentication process, attackers or malicious clients attempt to deceive the server with a message that has been verified before. Nevertheless, in the proposed authentication algorithm, the timestamp t‚Äãsiùë°subscriptùë†ùëñts_{i} and FL round number tùë°t are utilized in the calculation of parameters MisubscriptùëÄùëñM_{i} and SisubscriptùëÜùëñS_{i}. Therefore, if an attacker utilizes a previous timestamp to participate in the authentication process, the server will accurately identify that it is an expired authentication message. Similarly, suppose that an attacker constructs an authentication message based on the latest timestamp. In that case, the authentication process will not be completed (the proposed authentication algorithm can effectively resist tampering attacks and forgery attacks). Thus, our proposal can effectively resist the replay attack. ‚àé
